Key Highlights for Medical Decision-Maki:
- Inconsistent documentation across two notes on same visit date: conflicting statements regarding prior labs, eye exams, kidney disease history. Establish a single, reconciled HPI.
- Lack of documented home blood glucose monitoring data; encourage patient to record readings to guide therapy titration.
- No explicit rationale documented for choice of semaglutide over other second-line agents (e.g., SGLT2 inhibitors) given kidney disease and cost considerations.
- Preventive care gaps not addressed in early MDM: immunizations, foot and eye exam scheduling, social determinants of health impacting adherence.
- No documentation of blood pressure or microalbuminuria targets, or plan for ACE inhibitor/ARB to slow CKD progression.
- Medication reconciliation incomplete: metformin dosing history unclear, timing of last dose, reason for extended-release formulation.
- Contingency planning limited: no if-then statements for side effects, hypoglycemia, or lack of A1c response.
Chief Concern: Lab follow-up for type 2 diabetes management and refill of metformin
Assessment: Bill Moore is a 75-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed in 2023, presenting for lab review and medication refill. He reports no new symptoms but admits to six months without metformin, poor diet, no exercise, and significant psychosocial stress. Objective data: A1c 9.8%, creatinine 1.6 mg/dL (eGFR 55 mL/min/1.73 m²), microalbuminuria (50 mg/g), LDL 137 mg/dL, BMI ~36.5, BP 132/84. He has stage 3a CKD and microvascular risk. Likely diagnosis: inadequate glycemic control due to non-adherence and suboptimal regimen. Differential: 1) Persistent hyperglycemia from non-adherence vs inadequate regimen; 2) CKD progression secondary to diabetes; 3) dyslipidemia driving cardiovascular risk.

Problem 1.Status: Not at goal; A1c 9.8%; ongoing hyperglycemia
Problem 1.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Reviewed labs showing A1c 9.8%. No home glucose data; patient to obtain glucometer and record fasting and post-prandial readings for 2 weeks. Consider CGM if adherence issues persist.
Problem 1.Treatment/Medication Plan:
• Metformin ER 500 mg: increase from no current dose to 500 mg BID first week, then 1000 mg BID as tolerated (max 2000 mg daily).  
• Semaglutide subcutaneous: start 0.25 mg weekly for 4 weeks, then increase to 0.5 mg weekly; titrate to 1.0 mg based on tolerance and glycemic response.  
• Alternatives: empagliflozin 10 mg daily if injectable intolerance or cost barrier (renal benefit, weight loss).
Problem 1.Contingency Planning:
• If nausea or vomiting with semaglutide: hold dose, resume at prior tolerated dose; consider switching to dulaglutide.  
• If A1c remains >8% at 3 months: add basal insulin (glargine) with start 10 units nightly and titrate.
Problem 1.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Document baseline home glucose values and regimen adherence history; specify titration schedule and patient education on injection technique.
Problem 1.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Assess patient’s prescription coverage before semaglutide; consider SGLT2 inhibitor or sulfonylurea (glipizide) if cost prohibitive, with counseling on hypoglycemia risk.

Problem 2.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Monitor eGFR and albumin/creatinine ratio every 3 months. Screen for other causes of CKD if decline >5 mL/min/year.
Problem 2.Treatment/Medication Plan:
• Initiate lisinopril 5 mg daily, titrate to 10–20 mg to target BP <130/80 mm Hg and reduce albuminuria.  
• Maintain metformin use until eGFR <30.
Problem 2.Contingency Planning:
• If hyperkalemia >5.5 mmol/L: reduce or hold ACE inhibitor; consider ARB or diuretic.  
• If eGFR falls below 45: re-evaluate metformin safety; adjust semaglutide dosing.
Problem 2.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Stage CKD explicitly in note; record rationale for ACE inhibitor initiation and target BP.
Problem 2.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Use generic lisinopril; monitor potassium and creatinine per protocol to avoid costly hospitalizations.

Problem 3.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Calculate ASCVD risk; guideline indication for moderate- to high-intensity statin in diabetic age >75.
Problem 3.Treatment/Medication Plan:
• Atorvastatin 40 mg daily (generic) to target LDL <70 mg/dL.  
• Counsel on dietary fat reduction.
Problem 3.Contingency Planning:
• If statin intolerance (myalgias): reduce to 20 mg or switch to pravastatin.  
• If LDL remains >70 mg/dL at 3 months: add ezetimibe 10 mg daily.
Problem 3.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Document ASCVD risk score and rationale for statin intensity.
Problem 3.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Use generic atorvastatin; defer PCSK9 inhibitors unless refractory.

Problem 4.Status: Not at goal; BMI ~36.5, no exercise
Problem 4.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Assess readiness for change; refer to dietitian and diabetes education.
Problem 4.Treatment/Medication Plan:
• Provide medical nutrition therapy referral.  
• Encourage 150 minutes/week of moderate exercise (walking).
Problem 4.Contingency Planning: • If no improvement in 3 months: consider referral to structured weight-management program or behavioral health.
Problem 4.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Document lifestyle counseling details and patient’s stated goals.
Problem 4.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Use community-based exercise programs and free online nutrition resources.

Problem 5.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Identify barriers: psychosocial stress, divorce. Screen for depression.
Problem 5.Treatment/Medication Plan:
• Provide pill organizer and medication calendar.  
• Synchronize prescriptions with one monthly fill.  
• Offer social work referral for coping support.
Problem 5.Contingency Planning: • If continued non-adherence: consider home health visits or telehealth check-ins.
Problem 5.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Record patient’s adherence barriers and agreed-upon support plan.
Problem 5.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Use low-cost pill boxes; coordinate refills to reduce pharmacy trips.

Problem 6.Decision Making and Diagnositic Plan: Review immunization records; schedule diabetic eye and foot exams.
Problem 6.Treatment/Medication Plan:
• Refer to ophthalmology for retinopathy screening.  
• Schedule foot exam with primary or podiatry every visit.  
• Update immunizations: influenza, pneumococcal, zoster.
Problem 6.Contingency Planning:
• If patient misses specialist appointments: arrange transportation assistance.  
• If immunizations refused: document counseling and plan to revisit.
Problem 6.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Include a preventive care checklist in the note.
Problem 6.Considerations for Cost Effective Care I: Use standing orders and clinic immunization stock to reduce referral costs.

Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item 1: Influenza vaccination annually to reduce respiratory infection risk in elderly and diabetic patients.
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item 2: Pneumococcal vaccines (PCV13 then PPSV23) per CDC schedule for age >65 and CKD.
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item 3: Herpes zoster recombinant vaccine (2 doses) to prevent shingles complications.
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item 4: Diabetic retinopathy screening annually via ophthalmology.
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item 5: Foot exam with monofilament testing at each diabetes visit to detect neuropathy early.
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Item 6: Age-appropriate cancer screening review: consider colorectal screening status if no prior colonoscopy.
Anticipatory Preventative Care.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Implement a standardized health maintenance template capturing all immunizations and screening dates.

Follow Up Care.Item 1: Recheck A1c, CMP, albumin/creatinine ratio, lipid panel in 3 months to assess therapy efficacy.
Follow Up Care.Item 2: Measure home blood glucose logs at 2-week and 3-month visits to guide titration.
Follow Up Care.Item 3: Monitor blood pressure and renal function monthly until stable on lisinopril.
Follow Up Care.Item 4: Review semaglutide tolerability after 4 weeks; adjust dose accordingly.
Follow Up Care.Item 5: Confirm ophthalmology report from 2/20 visit and schedule next annual exam.
Follow Up Care.Item 6: Assess medication adherence and psychosocial status at next visit; screen for depression.
Follow Up Care.Considerations for Documentation Improve: Use follow-up visit checklists with pending items and responsible party clearly noted.
